content: Ha! I think I could argue Google Fiber was everything it was intended to be. The potential threat of The Mighty Google would inspire the established access provider superpowers to up their game (i.e. increase their coverage and speed). We’re seeing this happen, yes?Fact: More and faster access —regardless of the provider —is good for Google. Google Fiber’s losses can’t be measured by just looking at the silo alone. Context matters. If #1 worked, and it appears it has (at least to some extent) then Fiber’s ROI is positive. Imagine that, enter a handful of markets and see the broader pie grow. A lot.Worst case, that play fails. Then Google is in a position — evidence in hand — to lobby the government, as well as the public on how the established superpowers are neglecting their duties.Google doesn’t need to do EVERYTHING. It just wants to show it can be done. Google is an algorithm company first, with product company being a distant second. (Yes, of course, there are a couple outlier exceptions.) If Google can manipulate (?) the market to play to Google’s strengths — without Google having the take on the entire market — then Google will figure out how to leverage those changes and add to its bottom line. I don’t disagree with your analysis per se. I’m just not so sure your context is broad and complete enough. I’m not suggesting I’ve nailed it either — just that there’s a bit more here to consider. And I wanted to make some food for thought suggestions.
